scientific_summary: Positive emotion broadens cognition and builds resources (Fredrickson, 2004). Reinforcing savoring and prosocial acts sustains well-being.

immediate.title: Savor three breaths
instructions: Pause and breathe in slowly for four counts while noticing one pleasant sensation.
Hold for two counts as you label the feeling (e.g., warm, light, energized).
Exhale for six counts, mentally repeating the word that captures the joy.

evidence.summary: Brief savoring exercises broaden thought–action repertoires and enhance positive affect.

immediate.title: Share the good news
instructions: Send a quick message to someone you trust describing the moment of joy in one sentence.
Ask them to celebrate with you (e.g., 'Can we take 30 seconds to enjoy this victory?').
Notice their response and jot one word about how the sharing felt.

evidence.source: Gable et al., Journal of Personality and Social Psychology, 2004
evidence.summary: Capitalization (sharing positive events) increases relationship satisfaction and positive affect.

immediate.title: Power of posture
instructions: Stand or sit upright, opening your chest and extending arms outward for 30 seconds.
Smile gently and breathe in through the nose, out through the mouth.
As you exhale, name one word that captures the joy in your body.

evidence.summary: Expansive postures enhance positive affect and perceived resourcefulness.

short_term.title: Gratitude triad
instructions: List three things that went well in the last 24 hours.
Write one sentence for each about why it happened.
Close your eyes and re-experience the feelings for 10 seconds per item.

evidence.source: Emmons & McCullough, Journal of Personality and Social Psychology, 2003
evidence.summary: Daily gratitude journaling boosts positive affect and life satisfaction.

short_term.title: Micro act of kindness
instructions: Identify one tiny supportive act you can complete today (text encouragement, small favor).
Complete the act mindfully, focusing on intention rather than outcome.
Reflect on how the act reinforced your sense of connection.

evidence.source: Lyubomirsky et al., Review of General Psychology, 2005
evidence.summary: Intentional acts of kindness increase sustained positive emotion and well-being.

short_term.title: Strength spotting
instructions: Review a recent joyful event and list three personal strengths you used (creativity, humor, perseverance).
Describe how each strength contributed to the moment.
Plan one way to apply one of the strengths tomorrow.

evidence.summary: Identifying and applying signature strengths sustains happiness gains.

long_term.title: Positive portfolio review
instructions: Collect mementos (photos, quotes, notes) representing moments of joy.
Once per week, review the collection and write one new insight about what sparks joy for you.
Update the portfolio with one additional item that emerged during the week.

evidence.summary: Positive reminiscence exercises enhance happiness and reduce depressive symptoms.

long_term.title: Flow map planning
instructions: List activities where you lose track of time (flow states).
Schedule one session in the next week, noting time, place, and resources needed.
After the activity, journal one sentence on how the experience influenced your energy.

evidence.source: Csikszentmihalyi, Flow: The Psychology of Optimal Experience, 1990
evidence.summary: Deliberate engagement in flow-promoting tasks sustains positive mood and engagement.

long_term.title: Prosocial joy calendar
instructions: Map out one meaningful prosocial activity (volunteering, mentoring, community event) for the coming month.
Schedule it with a specific date and partner if possible.
After completing the activity, journal the emotional impact and lessons learned.

evidence.source: Aknin et al., Social Psychological and Personality Science, 2013
evidence.summary: Regular prosocial engagement amplifies positive affect and life satisfaction over time.

friend_support.title: Celebrate their win
instructions: Ask your friend to replay the joyful moment in detail while you listen closely.
Mirror back specific strengths you heard ("Your dedication really paid off").
Offer a small ritual to mark the joy together (toast, shared song, short walk).

evidence.source: Gable & Reis, Journal of Personality and Social Psychology, 2010
evidence.summary: Active-constructive responding to good news deepens relational satisfaction and joy.

friend_support.title: Amplify their possibilities
instructions: Invite your friend to imagine one way their joyful moment could grow into something larger.
Brainstorm together one supportive step you can take to help (introduction, resource, accountability).
Schedule a follow-up check-in to hear what unfolded.

evidence.summary: Broadening-and-building behaviors from close others increase joy durability.

self_repair.title: Repair after dampening joy
instructions: Own the dampening behavior ("I downplayed your news earlier").
Express genuine appreciation for their achievement or happy moment.
Ask how they would like to celebrate now and follow through.

evidence.summary: Repairing capitalization failures restores positive emotion and trust in relationships.

self_repair.title: Set a support intention
instructions: Reflect on why you minimized someone’s joy (stress, envy, distraction).
Plan a concrete action that spotlights their success (public praise, gift, quality time).
Commit to a reminder system (calendar, note) so future celebrations receive full attention.

evidence.source: Imrie et al., The Journal of Positive Psychology, 2019
evidence.summary: Intentional celebration plans increase supportive behaviors and shared happiness.
